postsData.name:
Michael Walker Ed.D.
Michael Walker Ed.D.
postsData.content:
𝗪𝗵𝗶𝗰𝗵 𝘄𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗵𝗼𝗼𝘀𝗲: 𝗔 𝗴𝘂𝗮𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗲𝗱 $𝟱𝟬 𝗼𝗿 𝗮 𝟱𝟬% 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝘄𝗶𝗻 $𝟭𝟬𝟬?

Most people take the sure $50—even though the gamble has the same expected value.

Why? 𝗕𝗲𝗰𝗮𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝘄𝗲 𝗳𝗲𝗮𝗿 𝗹𝗼𝘀𝘀𝗲𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝗻 𝘄𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲 𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗶𝘃𝗮𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗴𝗮𝗶𝗻𝘀—that’s loss aversion in action.

How a decision is framed shapes how we perceive risk, reward, and urgency.

In a famous study by Tversky & Kahneman (1981), participants were given two options for treating a deadly disease:

 Gain Frame: “This treatment will save 200 out of 600 lives."
 Loss Frame: “This treatment will result in 400 deaths out of 600."

Even though both statements describe the same outcome, far more people chose the "save 200 lives" option.

𝗪𝗵𝘆?
 We fear losses more than we desire gains.
 Losing feels twice as painful as an equivalent gain feels rewarding.
 The way information is framed shifts our perception of risk.

𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝘁𝗼 𝗨𝘀𝗲 𝗙𝗿𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗕𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗗𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀:
 𝗘𝗺𝗽𝗵𝗮𝘀𝗶𝘇𝗲 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁’𝘀 𝗮𝘁 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗲: Instead of saying, “Sign up for benefits,” highlight the loss: “Don’t miss out on your exclusive benefits.”
 𝗧𝘂𝗿𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝘀𝘁𝘀 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗼 𝗶𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀: Rather than “This course costs $500,” say “Invest $500 to boost your career and increase your earning potential.”
 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗰𝗵𝗼𝗶𝗰𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗮𝘂𝗹𝘁: Set the preferred option as the automatic choice, like “Your subscription renews automatically—cancel anytime.”

When you are making a decision, ask yourself: 𝗔𝗺 𝗜 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗰𝗵𝗼𝗶𝗰𝗲—o𝗿 𝘁𝗼 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗶𝘁 𝗶𝘀 𝗳𝗿𝗮𝗺𝗲𝗱?

𝗪𝗮𝗻𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗿𝗼𝘃𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻-𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴? Attend my Workshop on Feb. 19th:
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights on loss aversion! It’s fascinating how framing can drastically influence our decision-making. Excited for the workshop!

Hey LinkCom 
———————————————————————

 𝐖𝐞’𝐫𝐞 𝐨𝐟𝐭𝐞𝐧 𝐭𝐨𝐥𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐞𝐞𝐤 𝐛𝐚𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐢𝐧 𝐥𝐢𝐟𝐞 — 𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐥 𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤 , 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐭 , 𝐟𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐥𝐲 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐡𝐨𝐛𝐛𝐢𝐞𝐬

But here’s the truth :


️ 𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐞 — 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐭𝐨𝐩 𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐞𝐫𝐬, 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐠𝐚𝐦𝐞 𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐞𝐫𝐬 , 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐲 𝐦𝐚𝐤𝐞𝐫𝐬 — 𝐚𝐫𝐞𝐧’𝐭 𝐛𝐚𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞𝐝.

️ 𝐓𝐡𝐞𝐲 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐨𝐛𝐬𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐞𝐝. 𝐅𝐨𝐜𝐮𝐬𝐞𝐝 . 𝐀𝐥𝐥 𝐢𝐧


 𝐁𝐚𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐜𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐬 :

 Comfort
 Obsession
 Mastery


️ A balanced athlete trains a few hours a day while an elite one wakes up before dawn , sacrifices weekends and pushes beyond limits .

️ The world’s best don’t strive for balance. They strive for greatness.


 𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐠𝐧𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐡𝐢𝐝𝐞𝐬 𝐛𝐞𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐝 :

 Comfort

️ A perfectly balanced life often means no extreme struggles but also no extreme wins .

️ Growth isn’t found in balance — it’s found in intensity, sacrifice and pushing limits.


 𝐄𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐞 𝐤𝐧𝐨𝐰 𝐰𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐭𝐨 𝐠𝐨 𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐢𝐧

️ This doesn’t mean burnout is the goal . It means knowing when to go all in and when to recover .

️ They weren’t balanced. They were purpose driven .


Greatness demands sacrifice, obsession and relentless effort . Balance can come later — but first , you must build .


Ps - 𝘛𝘩𝘦 𝘰𝘯𝘦𝘴 𝘸𝘩𝘰 𝘨𝘰 𝘢𝘭𝘭 𝘪𝘯 𝘤𝘩𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘸𝘰𝘳𝘭𝘥 . 𝘛𝘩𝘦 𝘰𝘯𝘦𝘴 𝘸𝘩𝘰 𝘴𝘦𝘦𝘬 𝘣𝘢𝘭𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦 𝘸𝘢𝘵𝘤𝘩 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘮 𝘥𝘰 𝘪𝘵

postsData.content:
Challenge Your Comfort Zone This Week!

As athletes, we often find ourselves pushing physical limits, but what about our mental and emotional boundaries? This week, I challenge you to step outside your comfort zone.

**What’s one thing you can commit to that makes you feel a little uncomfortable?**

It could be striking up a conversation with a teammate you’ve never spoken to, trying a new training technique, or even sharing your personal goals with a mentor. Each small step can lead to significant growth both on and off the field.

Remember, growth happens when we embrace discomfort. By challenging ourselves, we not only enhance our skills but also develop resilience and confidence – essential traits for success in athletics and life!

I’d love to hear what you decide to tackle this week. Share your challenges below, and let’s support each other in our journeys!
postsData.commentAdded: Great challenge! Im committing to reaching out to a mentor for guidance this week. Excited to see how this push helps me grow! 💪🌟

Ani Filipova
Ani Filipova
postsData.content:
The easiest way for a boss to hide their incompetence? Blame you.

When you succeed -
It is because of their great management skills.

When you struggle -
it's because you are not good enough.

Most don’t even realise their own lack of skill is the real problem.

They never ask, “Did I fail as a leader?”
They assume “You just weren’t good enough.”

And they slap a label on you: lazy, slow, disorganised, incompetent.

Sound familiar? Here’s how to know if your boss is setting you up to fail:

1️⃣ No Clear Expectations:
Your role feels like a moving target.

2️⃣ Lack of Resources:
You’re expected to win with no resources.

3️⃣ Constant Micromanagement:
Every move and decision is second-guessed.

4️⃣ Excessive Criticism:
Mistakes are magnified. Wins are ignored.

5️⃣ Isolation:
You’re left out of key meetings and conversations.

6️⃣ Changing the Rules:
The goalpost keeps moving.

7️⃣ Your Confidence is Crushed:
You start doubting yourself.

Checked off 3 or more? It’s not just you.

Swipe through the carousel for exact steps to take back control.

 Know someone dealing with this? Tag them below.
 Repost to help others spot the signs and follow me,for career advice that actually helps.

comments.commentText: When a leader fails to take responsibility, they often shift the blame onto you. True leadership is not about claiming credit, but owning accountability.

postsData.content:
With the right leadership, the UK could compete with the US in so many ways… but a lot needs to change: 

Including our attitude towards success, entrepreneurship and failure.

comments.commentText: I completely agree with your perspective on the UK's potential to compete with the US Steven Bartlett. However, I believe that in addition to changing our attitude towards success, entrepreneurship and failure, we also need to focus on fostering a culture of innovation and creativity. This means investing in education and research, encouraging collaboration between businesses and universities, and providing support for startups and small businesses. Furthermore, we need to prioritize diversity and inclusion in our workforce, as diverse teams have been shown to be more innovative and successful. By embracing these changes, I believe that the UK can truly become a global leader in innovation and entrepreneurship.

The UK possesses extraordinary potential to compete with the US on the global stage, yet it is clear that we need a transformative shift in our mindset and approach. This shift transcends mere policy adjustments and demands a cultural renaissance.

We must create an environment that embraces innovation, wholeheartedly celebrates the entrepreneurial spirit, and reframes setbacks as invaluable learning experiences rather than failures. Moreover, we must urgently tackle our energy dependency. The soaring costs are not just a temporary setback; they significantly drag on our economy, affecting households and businesses alike.

To unlock our true potential, we need bold, visionary leadership that confronts these challenges head-on and galvanises a new era of ambition and resilience. What critical changes do you believe are necessary for the UK to truly thrive? Let’s engage in this vital discussion!

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Cultivating a growth mindset and embracing risk are crucial for fostering innovation and driving competitiveness. Let’s champion change!

postsData.content:
The biggest wealth transfer in history is happening right now:

The next wave of millionaires won't come from startups...

They'll come from old businesses that embrace this ONE thing.

Here's the SMB strategy that will dominate the next decade:

$72.6 trillion will move between generations by 2046.

The startup game is getting harder - 90% fail within 5 years.

But there's a massive opportunity hiding in plain sight:

32.5M small businesses in the US alone are ready for transformation.

I call it SMB 2.0:

The fusion of old economy infrastructure with new economy technology.

Think about Tesla - it's not a car company, it's a software company that happens to make cars.

The data is crystal clear.

Digitally mature companies are:

• 50% more likely to grow revenue
• 8x more likely to create jobs
• 14x more likely to innovate
• 3x more likely to export

But most of these businesses are held back by legacy systems, costing them 15% in revenue annually.

Let me show you a real example:

Ace Hardware's digital transformation resulted in:

• 3.5x increase in online sales
• 28% higher transaction sizes
• 15% reduction in inventory costs
• 98% higher customer satisfaction

Manufacturing companies implementing AI and IoT are seeing:

• 80% reduction in prototyping time
• 50% reduction in time-to-market
• 20% reduction in downtime
• 30% reduction in costs

By 2025, 75% of business leaders will be leveraging digital platforms to adapt to new markets.

After facilitating over $200M in acquisitions, I've learned the key to capitalizing on this wealth transfer isn't just technology.

You need three things:

• Access to the right deals
• A proven framework for evaluating opportunities
• A clear roadmap for post-acquisition transformation

The entrepreneurs who succeed aren't the most tech-savvy.

They're the ones who understand how to identify undervalued businesses and deliver real improvements.

Buy then build.

-

postsData.content:
3 years ago this week, I quit my day job to go all in on Bloom. 

I remember imagining this moment beforehand, thinking it would be a daunting decision.

It wasn't at all.

It was one of the easiest decisions I've ever made.

I felt peace, confidence, and total excitement.

It had been my dream to build something mission-driven since I was a teenager.

I remember telling my parents, "I want to do something with my life that helps people abroad, but I don't know what."

And in the early, validation days of, we saw our first team members overseas more than double their income.

Plus, our first clients told us our staff were just as good as US talent and they already wanted to hire more from us.

I knew we were onto something special. A once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

And I had a partner inwho was just as all-in as I was.

So it was easy to make the leap.

Now 2025 marks our FOURTH year of business! 

We're arguably the fastest-growing bootstrapped business in the state of Utah.

Impacting thousands of people around the globe who have joined our staff.

And revolutionizing how work is done for our clients — household-name companies that people use every day.

I'm nostalgic this week thinking back to making the plunge 3 years ago, but I'm even more excited for the next 3 years ahead.

We're just at the beginning of our story.

postsData.content:
Our kids don't want our life.

Who could blame them?

This is what success looks like for a lot of people today:

- a fancy title
- asking for permission
- never seeing your kids
- never being present with people you love
- asking for growth and waiting to be promoted
- counting down the days until vacation each year
- waiting for a boss to give you 2% salary increase
- coming back from vacation thinking: "now it’s going to be different, I won’t let work rule my life”. 2 days goes by: you’re in the same sh!t
- so tired from sitting in back to back meetings all day that you’ve started to forget who you are and started dying from the inside

→ This is just being hi-jacked 24/7.

We seriously need to REDEFINE what success looks like.

It should be:

- owning our time
- not be held back
- setting our own rules
- design the life we want
- decide our own income
- ownership and accountability
- having time to experience life
- working from wherever we want
- time with family and being present
- waking up every day feeling challenged, curious, excited, hungry and at the same time content with life

The traditional 9-to-5 is just a hamster wheel.

It's a broken old model that hasn’t been updated in a very long time.

It leaves you zero autonomy.

→ It does its job though: it keeps you busy and focused on just getting through the day.

It leaves you no time to do anything else than building someone else's dream.

We have to do better than this.

Do you agree?



️ Repost this to your network, and follow mefor more content about entrepreneurship, personal branding, and leveraging the attention economy to build profitable online businesses.

comments.commentText: Success isn't just about having money, it's about having money and freedom as well Hanna Larsson

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Its time to prioritize fulfillment and redefine success on our own terms. Lets embrace autonomy and live life fully!

postsData.content:
The gregariousness of the human species, the formation of clans and tribes, groups and societies, sects and religions, nations and States, all tend to one fundamental end, the finding of oneness in this world of infinite variation, the unity that eludes but which is in the heart of things, secret, yet, sending ever the message that it lies in wait to be discovered, the profound end of evolution, the transcendence of phenomenal life, the infinitude of existence. Man hears this voice of freedom coming from within but mistakes its source as a revelation from without from an omnipotent arbiter inhabiting a higher heaven with a rod to strike the errant one who chooses not to fall in line with the dictum from above. Fear and ignorance and their foster-child arrogance have thus gripped the world for ages, superstition bred in the primitive mind devoid of enlightenment of reason or real inspiration have plunged the world with bloodshed such that we feel the echoes of those ancient clashes even today with technological tentacles holding us in their death-grip like never before. But there is hope as well. Scientific knowledge and the Vedanta are releasing humanity from the insensate culture of its brutal past and the combination of the two will bring forth a renaissance of all that has been highest and noblest in human history with added discoveries of the future ushering in a golden age for all of humankind. There will be resistance, often violent ones, to thwart the progress of man for the conservative element in the organic system is hard to rid of, but victory shall be sealed with fresher generations seeing the light of day and accepting what is true and best in human culture as the future man scales higher peaks en route to the summit of realizations that we are outwardly many, inwardly one. An enforced homogeneity will not work for it is against the basic principle of Nature, the variegation of life built on the foundation of the essential oneness of existence. Unity in diversity will have to be accepted as the one basis for a variegated flowering of the human species. Only on such an enlightened acceptance of each other may we be sure of the promotion of peace and harmony of the peoples of the world, only on such a universal understanding of truth may we be able to truly love our fellow-beings as we move towards a world civilization with a common agenda, the freedom of all, fellowship with all and the well-being of all that inhabit this beautiful home of ours, Planet earth.
Written by Sugata Bose

Ever walked into a room and instantly felt drawn to someone—not because they were the loudest or the most flamboyant, but because they carried an effortless sense of confidence and class?

That’s the silent power of 𝐜𝐨𝐫𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐭𝐭𝐞—the invisible yet defining factor that shapes how people perceive, respect, and remember you.

In my recent Corporate Etiquette Session with, we explored the fine nuances that separate professionals from true leaders.

Because in the corporate world, it's not just about what you do—it’s about how you carry yourself while doing it.

𝐇𝐞𝐫𝐞’𝐬 𝐰𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐰𝐞 𝐮𝐧𝐜𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐝: ⬇️

⦾ Grooming & Appearance: Like it or not, first impressions aren’t just lasting—they’re defining. The way you present yourself sends an instant message about your professionalism, confidence, and attention to detail.

⦾ The Power of Uniforms: Think of a uniform (whether literal or figurative) as your visual signature—a mark of discipline, unity, and personal branding.

Whether you’re in a tailored suit or business casual, how you wear it matters as much as what you wear.

⦾ Cubicle & Workspace Etiquette: Your workspace is an extension of you.

Cluttered desks, loud phone calls, or casual interruptions?

They might seem harmless, but they speak volumes about your work ethic and consideration for others.

⦾ Email & Communication Etiquette: Every email you send is a reflection of your personal brand—is it sharp, structured, and respectful, or rushed and careless?

Professionalism isn’t just about words, but how you say them.

⦾ Customer Service & Professionalism: Your success is built on more than just skills—it’s built on relationships. The way you handle interactions, resolve conflicts, and respond to challenges can either win loyalty or lose trust.

⦾ Interactive Activities & Role Plays: Because etiquette isn’t just about theory—it’s about application. We brought scenarios to life with role plays, self-reflection activities, and real-world problem-solving, ensuring that etiquette isn’t just learned—it’s embodied.

 The Takeaway?
Corporate etiquette isn’t about rigid rules—it’s a strategy for influence, credibility, and long-term career success.

The smallest refinements in your personal and professional behavior can create the biggest impact in your career.

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM – Part 5 – CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making today’s AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.
postsData.commentAdded: Exciting insights! Challenging outdated premises is crucial for AIs evolution. Looking forward to seeing how the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem progresses!

postsData.content:
I GOT LAID OFF… and it was the best thing that ever happened to me

I remember sitting at my desk, the ping of the email hitting my inbox

Subject: Organizational Restructuring.

I didn’t even need to open it to know what was coming. That sinking feeling hit me like a freight train—I was laid off. For a moment, the world seemed to stop.

What now? Mortgage payments, bills —how was I going to keep it all together?


It’s natural to feel defeated, overwhelmed, maybe even a little lost. First, change your state. Move your body, get outside, breathe deeply.

When I felt crushed, I didn’t stay in bed. I put on my running shoes and hit the pavement, joined a dance class, picked up cooking, socialized.

Motion creates emotion. When you shift your physiology, your mind follows.


When you’re laid off, it’s tempting to retreat into a shell, but that’s the exact opposite of what you need.

Don’t just send a bland, “Hey, I’m looking for work” message. Instead, let your network see your passion and skills. Post about what you’ve achieved, share what you’re excited about, and make it personal.

When I reached out to my network, I didn’t just ask for help—I showed them how I could add value. And the opportunities started rolling in.


A layoff might feel like a door closing, but what if it’s the universe forcing you to knock on the one that leads to your dream job?

I'd say “Life is happening for you, not to you.”


While you’re job hunting, carve out time to pursue the dream.

Always wanted to shift industries? Now’s the time.
Been eyeing that certification or side hustle? Dive in.

When I was laid off, I didn’t just settle for any job—I aimed higher. And guess what? I landed a role that paid more and aligned perfectly with my passions.


You are stronger than this moment. You are bigger than your job title. This layoff? It’s just a plot twist in your success story.

So feel the hit, eat that ice cream, but then GET UP. Rally your network, chase that dream, and show the world that a setback isn’t the end—it’s the fire that forges your next big win.

Because you, my friend, are unstoppable.

comments.commentText: This is the kind of perspective that turns setbacks into stepping stones. More people need to hear this Kiran Babu

You have a natural tendency to write messaging that assumes your reader knows what you know. 

Don’t worry, it’s not just you. We all have this tendency

We unconsciously assume other people see the inherent value of a feature the same way we see it.

It’s like if you’re a really great cook.

You have so much experience stored in your brain that you can’t remember what it was like to NOT know all that stuff.

So you dive into the nuances of achieving a fluffy soufflé for an audience that doesn’t know how to properly crack an egg 

No wonder so much tech messaging goes over people’s heads, right?

That’s why you want to get clear on your customer’s level of knowledge about your product.

Ask yourself:

– How tech-savvy are my customers?
– How solution-aware are my customers?

Use the answers to shape your messaging.

This will help you write without assuming your customers know what you know.

So you can meet them on their level

postsData.content:
AI isn't a magic wand for design... But when designers master the when and how of using AI in their workflow - the result can be amazing.


Last year, inspired by design educators likeand, and together with my colleague Shir Atar , I took on a challenge with my Industrial Design students at HIT: exploring how AI could fit into the design process.

The idea was simple but ambitious—learning by doing.The students developed their own methods for using AI tools, combining them with traditional techniques and personal insights. They didn’t stop there—they turned their discoveries into tutorial videos to share with the wider design community. Fast forward to today: we’re in the second year of this journey, and the results continue to inspire me.
This year, nine more student groups tackled diverse applications of AI in design, from AI-driven Ideation and AI-VR integration to re imagining mock-ups and 3D modeling workflows.
The outcome? A collection of tutorials showing how AI can elevate the design process, now available for anyone curious about integrating AI into their work.
A few lessons stand out from this experience:
Letting go of the fear of change makes experimenting with AI feel less intimidating—it’s just another powerful tool in our creative toolbox.
Starting small, like testing AI on one part of the design process, can spark new methods that inspire and elevate creativity.
The magic lies in personalization—finding the unique mix of tools that works for you.
It’s been a great experience to guide students as they explore how designers can shape the future with AI, rather than letting it shape us.
*Both the website and videos are in Hebrew, but (AI) subtitles are available we are working on a translated version to be up and running soon.

"Nobody cares about us."

These words changed how I saw culture.

They didn't come from our engineers.
They came from our competitor's engineers.

Context:
As a tech company, one of our services included
deploying engineers at client sites.

They worked alongside people from other vendors.

The industry norm?
Once deployed, they were out of sight, out of mind.

We refused to accept that.

Instead, we did this:
↳ Once a month, our HR visited them.

Not for paperwork.
Not for performance reviews.
Just to connect — human to human.

The ritual was simple:
→ Bring their favorite snacks
→ Share some laughs
→ Take fun pictures
→ Actually listen
→ Truly care

Tiny gestures. Massive impact.

What happened next surprised us:

1. Our engineers felt anchored
Even off-site, they knew they belonged.
(Loyalty and retention skyrocketed.)

2. Clients took notice
"You actually care for your people."
(We became their vendor of choice.)

3. Our competitor’s engineers took notice
"Nobody does this for us."
(We became their employer of choice.)

The big lesson?
Culture isn’t built inside your office.
↳ It’s built 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿 your people are.

Most companies think:
Out of sight = Out of mind.

Reality?
Out of sight = Needs more mind.

Checkout the exact frameworks we used to build strong bonds with off-site teams

postsData.content:
Great leaders take it in stride—even when it’s a brick to the face

Leadership is a lot like walking through a crowded street: no matter how smoothly you navigate, someone’s going to bump into you, step on your foot, or spill their coffee down your shirt. & if you’re leading anything worthwhile, you’re going to get hit with far worse—criticism, setbacks, & the occasional existential crisis over why you ever signed up for this in the first place.

The best leaders don’t just survive these moments; they take them in stride. They don’t flinch, don’t spiral, & definitely don’t rage-post on LinkedIn about how ungrateful their team is. They absorb the blow, recalibrate, & move forward like it was all part of the plan.

An HBR study found that leaders who demonstrate emotional resilience in the face of criticism or failure foster 33% higher engagement among their teams. Meanwhile, those who react poorly create a ripple effect of stress, disengagement, & occasional popcorn-worthy workplace drama.

In other words, when you take setbacks in stride, your team learns to do the same. & that’s how you build a culture that can actually handle pressure—instead of one that collectively loses its mind every time there’s a bad quarter.

Not sure if you take things in stride? Here’s a quick test:

• Someone gives you tough feedback. Do you: A) Thank them & reflect on it? (Good.) B) Spend the next 48 hours coming up with a strategic revenge plan? (Bad.)

• A project flops. Do you: A) Gather your team, assess what went wrong, & move forward? (Good.) B) Launch into a dramatic monologue about how nobody respects your genius? (Bad.)

• A team member challenges your decision. Do you: A) Listen & evaluate their perspective? (Good.) B) Reply with, "Do you know who I am?!" (Bad & also embarrassing.)

If you find yourself leaning toward the "bad" column, don’t worry. Here’s how you can develop this essential leadership skill:

1. Pause before you react — When hit with criticism or bad news, don’t react immediately. Take a breath. Count to six. Or, if necessary, step outside & scream into the void (privately).

2. Reframe the setback — Instead of seeing failures or critiques as personal attacks, view them as data. What can you learn? How can this make you better?

3. Keep the big picture in mind — Will this matter in a month? A year? Most things that feel like earthquakes today are barely speed bumps in hindsight.

4. Lead by example — If you panic, your team panics. If you stay cool, they stay cool. Simple as that.

Leadership will always throw curveballs your way. If you take every hit personally, you won’t last long. But if you take things in stride, you’ll build resilience—not just for yourself, but for your entire team.

So, the next time someone drops a load of criticism on you, just smile, nod, & keep moving. & maybe, just maybe, invest in a metaphorical helmet.

comments.commentText: Indeed - it’s not about avoiding setbacks, but about handling them with grace and turning them into learning opportunities.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Resilience in leadership is key to fostering a strong, united team. Its all about turning obstacles into growth opportunities! 🌱

postsData.content:
21 Worst Career Mistakes
(Fix them fast to accelerate your career):

1/ Solving problems that aren't yours.
↳ Let small fires burn. Build systems that prevent them.

2/ Staying because it's comfortable.
↳ Update your resume monthly. Interview before you're stuck.

3/ Making yourself irreplaceable.
↳ Document your role and train your replacement.

4/ Thinking work friends are real friends.
↳ Schedule coffee with someone two levels up. Monthly.

5/ Waiting for permission to lead.
↳ Find a broken process. Fix it without being asked.

6/ Playing the long-term game.
↳ Build skills that travel, not roots that trap.

7/ Avoiding office politics.
↳ Build three allies above your pay grade.

8/ Hiding behind hard work.
↳ Turn wins into visible process improvements.

9/ Trusting HR is on your side.
↳ Document everything. Build your own evidence trail.

10/ Saving questions for later.
↳ Ask the awkward question in the big meeting.

11/ Chasing titles over skills.
↳ Focus on building rare, valuable skills.

12/ Becoming too specialized.
↳ Learn adjacent skills. Build breadth and depth.

13/ Avoiding difficult conversations.
↳ Address issues early. Be direct but kind.

14/ Not building your network.
↳ Build one new connection weekly. Stay in touch monthly.

15/ Ignoring industry trends.
↳ Read industry news daily. Learn one new tool monthly.

16/ Taking credit instead of giving it.
↳ Highlight their contributions. Build through generosity.

17/ Not negotiating early offers.
↳ Research market rates. Ask for more than is comfortable.

18/ Staying too long in one role.
↳ Change roles every 2-3 years. Seek new challenges.

19/ Not building personal brand.
↳ Share insights weekly. Build thought leadership.

20/ Avoiding all risk.
↳ Take one calculated risk quarterly.

21/ Working without metrics.
↳ Define key success metrics. Track and share results.

---

When my husband scores a good parking spot, either in the first row or right by the door……

He says, “Nobody puts Baby in the corner.”

That’s me. I’m Baby. Lol. 

He’s been saying this for all of the 30 years we’ve been married.

The flying dance move, also made famous by the classic movie Dirty Dancin…. has been copied by tons of other movies.

It’s been performed at hundreds, if not thousands of weddings, parties and events.

You may have even attempted that move in the privacy of your own home with a trusted partner. (We listen and we don’t judge).

When Dirty Dancing came out, waaaaaay back in 1987, it was WIDELY panned by critics.

In fact, the most famous movie reviewers of the time, Rodger and Ebert gave it a paltry 1 star ⭐️.

But that didn’t stop people from loving it. It made over $170MM dollars within months of it’s release.

Just because something doesn’t always get the respect it deserves, doesn’t mean it’s not worth it.

Whether it’s a movie, your job or something else that doesn’t seem like it’s a good fit, there’s always someone else who will think it (or you) are amazing.

Sometimes, you just have to find the right audience.

When you hesitate too long, opportunities slip away.

Is overthinking slowing you down?

Or is it the fear of making the wrong decision?

Sometimes,
→ We get lost in too many options.
→ We wait for everything to be perfect.
→ We’re scared of making the wrong choice.

This leads to being stuck
and missed opportunities.

Hᴇʀᴇ ᴀʀᴇ 5 ᴛɪᴘꜱ ᴛᴏ ᴛᴀᴋᴇ ᴄᴏɴᴛʀᴏʟ ᴏꜰ ʏᴏᴜʀ ᴄʜᴏɪᴄᴇꜱ
ᴀɴᴅ ᴍᴏᴠᴇ ꜰᴏʀᴡᴀʀᴅ ᴡɪᴛʜ ᴄʟᴀʀɪᴛʏ:

𝟭/ 𝗟𝗶𝗺𝗶𝘁 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗢𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀
↳ Set a maximum of 3 choices.
↳ Eliminate irrelevant options.
↳ Focus only on top choices.

𝟮/ 𝗧𝗿𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗚𝘂𝘁
↳ Clear your mind first.
↳ Listen to your initial reaction.
↳ Make the decision fast.

𝟯/ 𝗜𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗳𝘆 𝗖𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿 𝗪𝗶𝗻𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗟𝗼𝘀𝘀𝗲𝘀
↳ Write down top outcomes.
↳ List pros and cons for each.
↳ Remove options that don’t align.

𝟰/ 𝗩𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗧𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝗟𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗠𝗼𝗻𝗲𝘆
↳ Set a 10-15 minute limit.
↳ Decide within the time frame.
↳ Stick to your decision.

𝟱/ 𝗧𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗹𝗲 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗿𝗮𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻
↳ Start with small decisions.
↳ Break big decisions into steps.
↳ Take action immediately.

Remember,
Your decisiveness grows
with every choice you make.

postsData.content:
How to Destroy a Deal in 45 Minutes (A Masterclass) 

Picture this: You get a pitch. 

It’s 12 pages long. It’s in Word (yes, Word).

It’s packed with more jargon than a legal thriller, and oh, there are seven different options to choose from.

Seven.

Like I’m at a buffet deciding between mashed potatoes or quinoa.

By the end of the pitch, I had:

• A headache.
• Zero understanding of what problem they could solve.
• And a deep, primal urge to set my inbox on fire.

Here’s what went wrong:

 They gave me everything but clarity.

 Instead of confidence, I felt like I needed a translator and a therapist.

 No one addressed the big question: What’s in it for me?

At the 45-minute mark, I tapped out.

I wasn’t interested. I wasn’t engaged. I was mentally googling “How to fake bad WiFi.”

Let’s get real:

No one cares about your company’s long history or how many words you can cram into a document.

Not until you can answer one simple question:

 Can you solve my problem?

If you’re pitching, here’s how not to suck at it:

️ Be clear. Like, “crystal-clear vodka” clear.

️ Tell me what’s in it for me. No jargon. No fluff.

️ Stop offering seven options. I barely trust myself to pick a sandwich.


The best pitch I ever got?

Two pages. One solution.

I walked away thinking, “Wow, they get it.”

So, please: don’t be the 12-page Word document of pitches.

Be the two-pager that wins.

What’s the worst pitch you’ve ever received?

How long does it take? 

To get your freelance business up and running so it brings in good clients on a reliable basis and turns a healthy profit?

That six months can be shortened to three months or can drag on for years.

Six months is just a reasonable timeframe for doing that.

By switching from windfall clients to system clients.

By understanding how leveraging 10% efficiency improvements translates into 100% profit bumps.

And by seizing on the enormous revenue potential of not being that good at the business stuff right now (seriously, that one shift will put more money in your pocket than anything else I can think of until you crack six figures).

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM – Part 4 – Update Agent LEARNING
Fundamental evidence of learning is the ability to recall and utilize what is learned. Receiving and integrating new information is a starting point. It is not learning, but an exceedingly small subset.
Recent research published in Nature uncovered that Concept Cells help our brain abstract information and build memories. (,)

A report in Quanta magazine () provides an example: The idea of a “bank” has its own set of concept cells, maybe millions of them. Concept neurons fire for their concept no matter how it is presented: in real life or a photo, in text or speech, on television or in a podcast. “It’s more abstract, really different from what you’re seeing,” said Elizabeth Buffalo, a neuroscientist at the University of Washington.

These discoveries support and align with the abstraction methodology discussed in Part 2 and the contextualization methodology in Part 3.



In contrast to how the brain learns, LLMs:
-process all ingested data rather than filtering for relevance, and
-output the detailed words and pixels based on statistical proximity rather than conceptual value
The aim is to pass the Turing test, output that imitates the appearance of intelligence sufficiently to deceive the user.

The correctness of the result is dependent on the concentrations of relevant data in the training content. AI speed hides the fact that the model does not “know” anything but rather recomputes even identical prompts.

On the other hand, by imitating the learning and memory architecture and methodology of the brain the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem creates a library of reusable expertise and continues to learn. Imagine the applications when expertise is in high demand but sparse due to "brain drain" scenarios, new science and technology, or economic constraints.

In part 5 I will discuss the curation methodology.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating insights on learning! Bridging brain mimicry and AI opens doors to innovative solutions in expertise management. Excited for Part 5!

Mirror, Mirror on the Wall
 Would I hire me at all?

Would I show up strong and true,
Or crack beneath a task brand new?
Do I lead with heart and grace,
Or just compete to win the race?

Mirror, mirror, tell no lies—
Do I inspire, or just advise?
Do I lift my team up high,
Or take the credit, let them sigh?

Would I trust me, take the leap,
Or fear the promises I keep?
Do I learn, adapt, and grow,
Or just pretend to always know?

Mirror, mirror, looking back—
Do I hold the skills I lack?
Do I blame, deflect, defend,
Or own mistakes and make amends?

If I were hiring, truth be told,
Would I see fire, brave and bold?
Or someone lost behind a mask,
Afraid to own the greater task?

Mirror, mirror, clear and bright—
Time to sharpen, time to fight.
Not just work, but who I be,
To make a team proud to have me.

Imagine moving to a new town, and feeling isolated because no one speaks your language. Now imagine that same town secretly learning your language—just to welcome you.
That’s exactly what happened to a deaf neighbour whose entire community learned sign language to surprise her. The moment she realized what they’d done? Pure, unfiltered joy. 
This isn’t just a story about inclusion. It’s a reminder that belonging is built by choice—one small act of kindness at a time.

 Why this matters:
1️⃣ Inclusion starts with effort – They didn’t wait for her to adapt; they met her where she was.
2️⃣ Community is a verb – It’s not just about living near each other; it’s about showing up for each other.
3️⃣ Small actions create big change – Learning a few signs transformed her world—and theirs.

To the people of this town: Thank you for showing us what true connection looks like.

postsData.content:
How I got 1,200+ shares on ONE LinkedIn post 

My LinkedIn post went viral. 

And by viral up, I mean…
 10,000+ followers overnight
 10 million views
 4,000+ comments

After that, I spent hours studying why it took off. What actually made people engage, share, and comment?

Here’s what I learned (and how you can apply it too):

 Your hook is everything.
→ If your first sentence doesn’t grab attention, nothing else matters.

Your hook should make people stop scrolling and feel curious enough to keep reading.

Pro tip: Study posts that go viral (especially from creators without huge followings) and analyse what made their opening line work.

________________

 Format matters more than you think.
→ No one wants to read a huge block of text. Make it skimmable.

Use spacing, emojis, and bullet points to break up ideas and keep people engaged.

________________

 Know exactly why you’re posting.
→ Before you hit publish, ask yourself: What’s the goal of this post?

Are you trying to educate, entertain, inspire, or start a conversation? The clearer your message, the better the engagement.

________________

 Use the algorithm to your advantage.
→ Whether we like it or not, the algorithm matters.

If LinkedIn is pushing selfies, post selfies. If engaging with comments early boosts reach, reply quickly. If a certain type of content is performing well, lean into it.

________________

The truth is, virality can be random—but there are patterns.

Once you recognise them, you can apply them to every post you create.

Which of these do you think makes the biggest difference? Let me know in the comments

You shouldn't care about your emotions.

Emotions are human.

But letting them take over is a choice.

95% people worldwide,
can't control their emotions.

Become part of the 5% today.

𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗿𝗲 3 𝗵𝗮𝗰𝗸𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗲𝗺𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀:

1. Your emotions are separate from your reaction
→ Your emotions should not decide your reaction.
→ How you react should suite the situation.
→ Your reaction should promote peace and growth.

2. Stop expecting people to behave like you
→ People don’t operate by your standards or values.

→ Focus on your own path, not that of others.
→ Just like you’re convinced of your truth, so are they.

Emotions aren't the problem.
How you handle them is.

postsData.content:
Want to stop clients from scope creeping?

Learn to ask this simple question:

Why?

I chat with agency owners weekly who speak about scope creep like it’s a disease they’ve been afflicted with.

I’m throwing a snowball at your head.

If a client scope creeps, and you let them, are we still seeing this as an unsolvable problem?

Here’s the antidote.

No fear. No combativeness. No awkward turtle.

Ask.
Them.
Why.

Example: I’ve served hundreds of manufacturing clients in my SEO career.

I’d always hear this: “We need to be on social media.”

This is what you hear: “They can pay me more.”

But you’ll find a way to underprice it
they’ll ask for more than you agreed
and the vicious cycle continues.

My approach?

“Why?”

It’s not your job to say yes.
It’s your job to serve them to the best of your ability.

My clients would often say, “We think it’s what we need to do.”

Again, “Why?”

Over and over and over I’d ask until we realized they thought it was a good idea but didn’t have a real reason.

Here’s how I’d serve them to the best of my ability:

“If we’ve established that it’s highly unlikely you’ll get more immediate business from social media, but you’re already seeing traction from our SEO work, can I propose that, if there’s more in the budget, we double down on what’s working instead of lose focus on something we don’t have a guarantee for?”

This is how you say no to a client.

They scope creep because you’re saying yes instead of serving them to the
best of your ability.

Cool? Cool.

Hate saying no to clients and need systems for how to do it effectively—without fearing churn?

comments.commentText: Love this, Colby. Asking “Why?” shifts the focus from just agreeing to actually understanding the core need - and often, clients realize they don’t need more, they just need what’s already working to be amplified.
What a great way to approach clients who think they can 'outsmart' the expert they just hired, or just want to do more, blindly betting on things that they 'feel' might work

postsData.commentAdded: Great advice! Asking Why? not only clarifies needs but also empowers us to guide clients toward the best solutions. 💡#ClientSuccess #AgencyGrowth

10 Powerful Lessons Life Has Taught Me


Life has been my greatest teacher, and along the way, I’ve learned lessons that have shaped me into who I am today.


Some came through wins, others through struggles, but all have been valuable.

Here are 10 things life has taught me:

'n Your mindset determines your reality. If you believe you can, you’re halfway there.

'n Nobody owes you anything. Take responsibility for your growth, your success, and your happiness.

'n Consistency beats talent. It’s not about how skilled you are; it’s about how often you show up.

'n Rejection is redirection. Every "no" is just pushing you closer to the right opportunity.

'n Your network is your net worth. Surround yourself with people who inspire and challenge you.

'n Done is better than perfect. Perfectionism kills progress. Start now and improve as you go.

'n Money flows where value goes. Focus on providing solutions, and opportunities will come.

'n Rest is productive. Burnout isn’t a badge of honor—listen to your body and recharge.

'n Learn to say no. Protecting your time and energy is self-respect.

'n You are your best investment. Never stop learning, growing, and betting on yourself.

𝑾𝒉𝒊𝒄𝒉 𝒐𝒇 𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒔𝒆 𝒍𝒆𝒔𝒔𝒐𝒏𝒔 𝒓𝒆𝒔𝒐𝒏𝒂𝒕𝒆 𝒘𝒊𝒕𝒉 𝒚𝒐𝒖 𝒕𝒉𝒆 𝒎𝒐𝒔𝒕? 𝑳𝒆𝒕’𝒔 𝒕𝒂𝒍𝒌 𝒊𝒏 𝒕𝒉𝒆 𝒄𝒐𝒎𝒎𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒔!
